Name: Acuna Island
Notes: This location is 1 km east of Acuna island and clearly has penguins, but the imagery available does not allow us to distinguish between chinstraps (which are more likely) or Adelies.

Name: Adams Island
Notes: See Southwell et al. (2013).

Name: Alasheyev Bight
Notes: Unclear if this location is the same as that previously referred to as "Alashevey Bight"; if not, this is a new colony.

Name: Amphibolite Point
Notes: Spectral information was used to distinguish Adelie penguins areas from chinstrap penguin areas.

Name: Ardley Island
Notes: Could not distinguish Adelie penguins from gentoo penguins in available imagery.

Name: Arthurson Ridge
Notes: We have assumed this is a new colony because it was not reported in surveys of neighboring colonies.

Name: Avian Island
Notes: There are two incongruent population estimates available for this colony in the 2012/13 field season (Lynch et al. Unpublished & the ASPA No. 117 Management Plan) and the available imagery is not of sufficient quality for a third population estimate. We have used the chick count by Lynch et al. (In Prep.) as the best available population estimate with the caveat that this is only an approximate measure of the number of breeding pairs.

Name: Backer Islands
Notes: This colony is in an area believed to have had penguins and so while no previous estimates exist, we do not have evidence to suggest this is a new colonization.

Name: Barrier Island
Notes: This colony is in the area covered by a recent aerial survey by Southwell et al. (2013) but this location was not noted and is therefore believed to be a new colony.

Name: Beaufort Island
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Beaufort North
Notes: Colony formed in 2004. Noted in LaRue et al. (2013).

Name: Bellingshausen Island
Notes: Not possible to distinguish Adelie penguins and chinstrap penguins in mixed colonies at Salamander Point in available imagery; best available estimates comes from recent field work described in Lynch et al. (In prep.). Considerable uncertainties both from the survey by Convey et al. (1999) and recent survey described in Lynch et al. (In Prep.) make it difficult to assess whether the apparent increase from <10,000 breeding pairs to ~45,000 breeding pairs (assuming one chick per breeding pair) is a true popualtion increase or a reflection of different estimation methods.

Name: Berthelot Islands
Source for assessing population change: Lynch et al. 2012 / Lynch et al. (2013)

Name: Biscoe Point
Source for assessing population change: Lynch et al. 2012 / Lynch et al. (2013)

Name: Bolingen/Lichen Island
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on available imagery.

Name: Brattstrand Bluff
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on available imagery.

Name: Brown Bluff
Notes: There was a count of 18630 (A3) adults from photographs made in the 2013/13 season (see Lynch et al. [2013]). This count would suggest a recent decline at Brown Bluff but the adult count is hard to interpret because the colony was not well established with nesting pairs at the time.

Name: Brownson Islands
Notes: This may be considered a collection of small colonies.

Name: Bruce Island
Notes: No prior information to allow us to distinguish between chinstrap and Adelie penguin breeding areas.

Name: Cape Adare
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Cape Anne
Notes: Cannot find colony in available imagery. See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Cape Bienvenue
Notes: Barbraud et al. (1999) report 15,023 pairs in 1997/98.

Name: Cape Bird
Notes: An analysis of imagery from 11/16/2010 gave an estimate of 53635 breeding pairs (95th percentile CI: [32574,88682]). We have used the field count reported in Lyver et al. (2014) because it is both more recent and more precise.

Name: Cape Bowles
Notes: The location contains mostly chinstrap penguins according to historical data but Adelie penguin breeding areas were selected based on apparent early arrival (comparing images from different dates).

Name: Cape Cornish/NE Buckle
Notes: Some databases indicate a colony at Cape Cornish but clouds over the exact location did not allow us to confirm it existence. This colony, referred to as Cape Cornish/NE Buckle, was very close to the stated location and may be the colony previously referred to as Cape Cornish.

Name: Cape Cotter
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Cape Crozier
Notes: An analysis of imagery from 12/12/2011 gave an estimate of 209830 breeding pairs (95th percentile CI: [128903,342501]). We have used the field count reported in Lyver et al. (2014) because it is both more recent and more precise.

Name: Cape Hallett
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Cape Jones
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Cape Omega
Notes: Two different images (dated 11/15/2009 and 12/12/10) were examined but there was no sign of the Cape Omega colony in either image. Because of uncertainties regarding the colony location, we cannot confirm the colony called Cape Omega has gone extinct, only that it cannot be found in its stated location.

Name: Cape Phillips
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Cape Pigeon Rocks
Notes: There is a major discrepency in the way Cape Pigeon Rocks and Way Archipelago have been divided over the historical record, with conflicting summaries in Woehler (1993) and Ainley (2002) relative to the original report by Ensor and Bassett (1987). Our assessment of population change for Cape Pigeon Rocks and Way Archipelago is contingent on this historical record and should be regarded cautiously.

Name: Cape Royds
Notes: An analysis of imagery from 1/20/2011 gave an estimate of 4209 breeding pairs (95th percentile CI: [2365,7119]). We have used the field count reported in Lyver et al. (2014) because it is both more recent and more precise.

Name: Cape Wheatstone
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Charcot Island
Notes: No cloud-free imagery available.

Name: Child Rocks Islands 1
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on imagery; poor images; reported in Low et al. (2007).

Name: Child Rocks Islands 2
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on imagery; poor images; reported in Low et al. (2007).

Name: Child Rocks Islands 3
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on imagery; poor images; reported in Low et al. (2007).

Name: Christoffersen Island
Notes: This island has a mix of all three Pygoscelis spp. species which cannot be distinguished in the available imagery.

Name: Clark Island
Notes: This colony is in an area believed to have had penguins and so while no previous estimates exist, we do not have evidence to suggest this is a new colonization.

Name: Continental Rock
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on available imagery which was of poor quality.

Name: Cormorant Point
Notes: There are penguins at this location but Coria et al. (2011) list both chinstraps and Adelies at this location; given the timing of the available imagery, what is seen on the image is likely to be chinstrap penguins.

Name: Coronation I: Other localities
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Coulman Middle
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Coulman North
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Coulman South
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Douglas Islands 1
Notes: Due to poor quality imagery, cannot confirm existence of this colony reported in Low et al. (2007).

Name: Douglas Islands 2
Notes: Due to poor quality imagery, cannot confirm existence of this colony reported in Low et al. (2007).

Name: Downshire Cliffs
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Duroch Island
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: d'Urville Monument
Notes: Imagery available makes it difficult to distinguish the precise boundaries of the Adelie breeding; the abundance estimate is highly approximate.

Name: Duthoit Point
Notes: Did not attempt to identify the single pair of Adelie penguins reported breeding at this lcoation.

Name: Etna Island
Notes: This is a very small colony that appears to be at low density so population estimate from the area is likely an overestimate of the true size.

Name: Ferrier Peninsula
Notes: Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas from chinstrap penguin breeding areas.

Name: Fish Islands
Source for assessing population change: Lynch et al. 2012 / Lynch et al. (2013)

Name: Fitchie Bay
Notes: Can’t tell where the original location is and cannot find unambiguous colony in this area although these are several islands with potential colonies but spp ID uncertain – I traced colony on what I think is most likely to be FITC

Name: Fliess Bay
Notes: This colony is not in a frequently visited area, so we cannot determine whether this is a newly colonized area or this colony has simply not been documented previously.

Name: Fortenberry
Notes: We have assumed this is a new colony because it was not reported in surveys of neighboring colonies.

Name: Franklin Island East
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Franklin Island West
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Gerlache Island
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Gibson Bay
Notes: Can’t see evidence of penguins breeding but the location is poorly specified and it is difficult to confirm the absence of a small colony in the imagery available.

Name: Gosling Island
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Gourdin Island
Notes: Recent field work (12/22/2012) at this location confirms the presence of breeding Adelie penguins but the available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among the three species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Gourlay Point
Notes: Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas but in some areas the Adelie penguins seem very low density so may have missed some areas with breeding Adelie penguins. Estimate here will be very approximate.

Name: Graptolite Island
Notes: Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas from chinstrap penguin breeding areas.

Name: Harald Bay
Notes: We have assumed this is a new colony because it was not reported in surveys of neighboring colonies.

Name: Henry Islands
Notes: Law (1962) notes that McLeod visited Henry Island and "found 100 penguins, of which two-thirds were chicks"

Name: Holdfast Point
Notes: This site includes the rocks just offfshore of Holdfast Point as well as a small colony on the mainland.

Name: Inexpressible Island
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Islet 1 Km west of Lavosier Island
Ivanhoff Head
Notes: Imagery unavailable for this location; reported in Southwell et al. (2013).

Name: Janet Rock
Notes: Location also called "Rochers".

Name: Joinville Is: small colonies
Notes: This is almost certainly the same colony referred to as Madder Cliff Island in Lynch et al. (In Press). The available imagery does not show the area of this colony so we use the abundance data reported in Lynch et al. (2013).

Name: Joubin Islands
Notes: No imagery available.

Name: King Point
Notes: This colony was noted in Croxall and Kirkwood (1979).

Name: Knobble Head, Bransfield Island
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Kujira Point
Notes: Cannot find this colony in the available imagery. This colony is reported as having ~30 pair in 1961 (Hoshiai et al. [1981]) but 0 pair in 1981 (Hoshiai et al. [1984]), and 7 adults (not clear if breeding or not) in 1984 (Ishikawa et al. [1988]).

Name: Lauff Island
Notes: Cannot find this colony in the available imagery.

Name: Lions Rump
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Llano Point
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.
column25: Nice image but cant distinguish among penguins

Name: Low Tongue
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on imagery; poor images; reported in Low et al. (2007)

Name: Madder Cliffs (Joinville Island)
Notes: Woehler (1993) calls this site "Joinville Island".

Name: Mame-zima
Notes: Mame-zima is only ~1 km from Meholmen Island; Either Mame-zima has gone extinct, or it has merged with Meholmen and therefore our estimate at Meholmen Island includes both of these locations.

Name: Mandible Cirque
Notes: Cannot find the colony; Cape Phillips and Mandible Cirque are lumped together in Ainley (2002). See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Montagu Island
Notes: The earlier estimate by Convey et al. (1999) appears to have missed the large colony of Adelie penguins near Scarlett Point which was discovered on the expedition described in Lynch et al. (Unpublished)

Name: Mount Gleadell
Notes: This colony is in a location that might not be visible from previous surveys, so we cannot determine whether this is actually a new colony or simply a breeding location not previously seen and reported.

Name: North Cape (d'Urville Island)
Notes: No well-timed imagery that would allow us to prove the existence of penguins breeding on the d'Urville Island coast and the location of this particular colony is uncertain.

Name: North Point
Notes: Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas but in some areas the Adelie penguins seem very low density so may have missed some areas with breeding Adelie penguins. Estimate here will be very approximate.

Name: Oldham Island
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on available imagery which was of poor quality.

Name: Oliphant Island
Notes: No Adelie penguins have been previously reported here, and this could be a gentoo penguin colony, but spectral signature suggests Adelie penguins and so this location has been included for future reconsideration.

Name: Outer Island
Notes: Impossible to determine if these penguins are Adelie penguins as all three pygoscelid penguins breeding in the vicinity.

Name: Pantomime Point
Notes: Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas but in some areas the Adelie penguins seem very low density so may have missed some areas with breeding Adelie penguins. Estimate here will be very approximate.

Name: Patella Island
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Peine Island
Source for last known population size: The note in Croxall and Kirkwood (1979) suggests the presence of breeding Adelie penguins at Peine Island.

Name: Penguin Island
Source for assessing population change: Lynch et al. 2012 / Lynch et al. (2013)

Name: Petermann Island
Source for assessing population change: Lynch et al. (2010) / Lynch et al. (2012)

Name: Point Martin
Notes: (Called Port Martin in Woehler and Croxell (1997) and several other sources.) Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas but in some areas the Adelie penguins were difficult to identify so may have missed some areas with breeding Adelie penguins. Any gentoo penguins and macaroni penguins breeding at this site may have been inadvertently included with the Adelie penguin breeding boundaries. Estimate here will be very approximate.

Name: Point Thomas
Notes: Some of the area identified as Adelie may be chinstraps breeding but there are only a few hundred chinstraps so the potential overestimation is relatively minor.

Name: Possession Island
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Powell Island South Coast (incl. Michelsen Island)
Notes: The count reported from Poncet and Poncet (1985) is a sum of the Powell north and south locations. The available imagery clearly shows penguins but it is not posisble to distinguish among the three species that are breeding here.

Name: Red Island
Notes: This colony does not appear to have been reported previously, but its location is sufficiently distant from previous surveys that we cannot determine if this is a new colonization or simply a new report of an existing colony.

Name: Rumpa Island
Notes: This colony was not found at the location provided.

Name: Saunders Island
Notes: This colony also referred to as "Ashen Hills".

Name: Saxum Nunatak
Notes: Available imagery too cloudy and location too unertain to confirm the existance or size of this colony.

Name: Sims Island
Notes: This colony does not appear to have been reported previously, but its location is sufficiently distant from previous surveys that we cannot determine if this is a new colonization or simply a new report of an existing colony.

Name: South Svenner
Notes: This colony does not appear to have been reported previously, but its location is sufficiently distant from previous surveys that we cannot determine if this is a new colonization or simply a new report of an existing colony.

Name: Spindrift Rocks
Notes: It was difficult to identify the penguins breeding at this location and there may be chinstap penguins inadvertently included with the Adelie penguin breeding boundaries.

Name: Stanton Continental Rock
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on available imagery which was of poor quality.

Name: Stanton Unnamed
Notes: Cannot confirm colony existence based on available imagery which was of poor quality.

Name: Stene Point
Notes: No penguins could be identified at this location but a few tiny breeding groups were identified 1 km northwest of STEN (see "1 km west of Stene Point")

Name: Stranger Point
Notes: Adelie breeding areas were distinguished from other species based on maps from Aguirre (1995)

Name: Sturge Island
Notes: No good imagery available.

Name: Sven Foyn Island
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Svenner Island
Notes: Ainley (2002) report 41,389 breeding pairs between Brattstrand Bluff and Svenner Island. This area is ONLY for Svenner Island. Brattstrand had no good imagery.

Name: Terra Nova Bay
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: The Wallows
Notes: No penguins previously reported here but imagery suggests both Adelie penguins and chinstrap penguins breeding at this location;  Adelie penguin breeding areas were preliminarily identified based on spectral information.

Name: Thule Island
Notes: Available imagery too cloudy for population estimation. The site with penguins breeding here is also referred to as "Hewison Point".

Name: Torinosu Cove
Notes: Unable to locate colony in the available imagery.

Name: Two islets next to Winkle Island
Unnamed 2
Notes: Although the imagery available (dated 12/28/2006) was of sufficient quality to detect penguin colonies, the colony noted by Low et al. (2007) at this location was not found.

Name: Unnamed 7
Notes: There was no imagery of sufficient quality to make a determination regarding this colony.

Name: Vestfold South
Notes: This may be considered a collection of small colonies.

Name: Watson Peninsula (East Coast)
Notes: Used spectral information to distinguish Adelie penguin breeding areas from chinstrap penguin breeding areas.

Name: Way Archipelago
Notes: See note for Cape Pigeon Rocks.

Name: Weddell Island
Notes: This colony has been reported to have several hundred gentoo penguins but we have delineated all the penguin breeding areas since it is not possible to separate the gentoo penguins in the available imagery and the vast majority of breeding penguins are Adelie penguins.

Name: Wide Open
Notes: Available imagery does not allow us to distinguish among multiple species of penguins breeding at this location.

Name: Wood Bay
Notes: See also Lyver et al. (2014).

Name: Yalour Islands
Source for assessing population change: Lynch et al. (2012) / Lynch et al. (2013)

Name: Young Island
Notes: No good imagery available.
